page.title: 02HISTORY - ASHDOWN FOREST
page.content: The Forest consists of 6400 acres of heathland with some woodland, is open to the public and administered by a Board of Conservators. It was formed from the Lancaster Great Park made by John of Gaunt in 1372. This park was surrounded by a bank and Pale, still traceable today. It was a Royal Game Park managed by foresters and keepers, and entered by gates where settlements and Iron workings arose and commoner's rights were established. By 1657 management had ceased, most of the trees felled for the iron industry and the deer gone. Much of the land was later sold or leased which interfered with the commoners ancient privileges. In the 19th century a High Court case resulted in an Act of Parliament allowing public access. This was confirmed in 1974.
